18 years ago this morning, our country came under attack.

Today, we pause to remember everyone who we lost on that terrible day, and to honor those who gave their lives in the service of helping and protecting others. #NeverForget

all of the soldiers and civilians who have been killed, maimed or scarred in Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria and elsewhere, our use of torture and extrajudicial execution, the neglect of education and health and human rights in favor of trillions spent on wars...

When I think of the almost incomprehensible amount of tragedy that followed 9/11, the misguided Iraq war, the notion of an endless and boundary-less ‚ÄúWar on Terror‚Äù (as if a nation can fight a war against a feeling)...

I also remember being the chair of the social action committee of our synagogue, Adat Shalom Reconstructionist Congregation in Bethesda. I had to give a speech on Yom Kippur. I said the world would never be the same. I guess that‚Äôs really true.

At the time, our three oldest kids (we eventually had a fourth) were 8, 5 and 3. Our elementary school and preschool had both dismissed so abruptly that Mary couldn‚Äôt get there fast enough to gather the boys at dismissal. She had to pick them up at friends‚Äô houses.

But when I did, Mary and I held each other for a long time, happy just to be alive, but also sensing that our country had turned a corner into an uncertain future where fear would likely play a bigger and unhealthy role.
I started walking north, until I got to a point where the subway was operating or I could get a cab or just kept walking - I honestly don‚Äôt remember how I made it home to Silver Spring.
Out in the sea of people on the street, after a period of group commiseration with colleagues and strangers alike, I decided I needed to get to my family ASAP.

I remember discussing whether we should walk to the Pentagon to help ‚Äî it would probably have taken an hour just to get there on foot ‚Äî with Damon Silvers, who works at the AFL-CIO to this day as policy director.
I Street and 16th Street were filled with people streaming out of buildings. The subway had been shut down. Most of us didn‚Äôt have cars, and anyway the streets were clogged.

At some point the building was evacuated. People realized that the White House was a target and we were in danger. I remember gathering my things as my colleagues who were emergency building captains urged us to hasten outside, but once we were there, there was nowhere to go.

We were all wandering around the 8th Floor in a daze, not knowing what to do. A while later, we went back into the conference room with its huge south-facing windows and looked sharply to the right, or west, where you could see a huge plume of smoke ‚Äî the Pentagon on fire.

I remember going down the hall to Arlene Holt-Baker‚Äôs office with her, because she had a TV. We started watching what was happening, and saw the completely incredible sight on live television of the second commercial jet hitting the south tower.

The image in my head and I bet the heads of others as well was of a biplane or other little tourist plane, because there had been a recent incident like that. Maybe then or maybe a few minutes later, Bob said, ‚ÄúI guess we should finish up and adjourn the meeting.‚Äù
But Bob sort of cocked his head and said to the group but also to no one in particular, because it was so odd, ‚ÄúHmmm, a plane hit the World Trade Center.‚Äù

President Sweeney‚Äôs chief of staff, Bob Welsh, was presiding, as usual. I remember Bob‚Äôs secretary, as she would still have been called then, Linda Hall, entering the room and passing Bob a note. That wasn‚Äôt uncommon.

I was the Assistant Director of Organizing at the AFL-CIO. By 9/11, I had already worked there for six years, since John Sweeney had become president of the labor federation in October, 1995. So it was as regular a part of my life as almost anything, those management meetings.

September 11, 2001 was a Tuesday. I remember because that‚Äôs the day the senior staff of the @AFLCIO met in the executive conference room on the 8th floor at 815 16th Street. The room has one of the great views in Washington, overlooking the White House across Lafayette Square.

Suicide is a senseless and preventable outcome for so many Americans, but we have to have the tools to identify when one of our loved ones is showing signs of depression, anxiety, and/or suicidal thoughts. Let's pass this bill and get our kids the support they need!

That's why I introduced HR 3778, the Cady Housh and Gemesha Thomas Student Suicide Prevention Act, which would give funding to schools so that school personnel and students can receive proper suicide awareness and prevention training.
Among America's youth, the issue is even more severe. Suicide is the 2nd leading cause of death for Americans aged 12-18, and 4 out of 5 teens who attempt suicide have given clear warning signs.

This week marks National Suicide Prevention Week, and it's important that we bring awareness to this awful epidemic. In the US, suicide is the 10th leading cause of death, with over 47,000 Americans dying by suicide in 2017.

That's 129 lives lost per day.
